index.txtUnivers:
LCDM and Dark Energy Models
Cosmological Calculator
index.txtTrajectoires: Trajectories in the metrics of Schwarzschild and of Kerr

univers.avertTropPoints: Too many points have been plotted, the calculation was stopped before reaching the bounds amin amax. Number of points plotted :
univers.infoH0: Current expansion rate of the universe (Hubble constant)
univers.infoTypeUnivers: You can choose the type of universe. If you choose classical, you can modify the omegas. Otherwise, one of the 4 omega will be equal to 1, the others to 0
univers.infoOmégaR0: Current radiation density parameter. It is calculated as an output but you can choose to set it to zero with "No CMB, No neutrinos" and choose whether or not to account for "Primordial Neutrinos"
univers.infoOmégaK0: Current curvature density parameter. You can set it to 0, which corresponds to a flat universe
univers.selecParam: You can select Ω<sub>Λ0</sub> and Ω<sub>m0</sub> by clicking on this chart:
univers.selecParamDE: You can select w<sub>0</sub> and w<sub>1</sub> by clicking on this chart:
univers.infoAmin: The plot will not go below this value. Cannot be greater than 1 if the universe has no beginning.
univers.infoAmax: The plot will not go above this value. Cannot be less than 1 if the universe has no beginning.
univers.infoNomFichier: Graph save name. Do not use special characters such as . * / | + \ and others

calculette.infobulle_generateur_graph: Part that generates different graphs based on the current parameters of the universe to see how these values evolve over time
calculette.infobulle_zmin: minimum value of z (lower than zmax)
calculette.infobulle_zmax: maximum value of z (higher than zmin)
calculette.infobulle_pas: number of points on the graph
calculette.infobulle_dependz: Performs the calculation with time as the abscissa axis
calculette.infobulle_dependt: Performs the calculation with redshift as the abscissa axis
calculette.infobulle_diametre_apparent: Part to obtain the apparent diameter theta as a function of the actual diameter (and vice versa) of the corresponding z
calculette.infobulle_D_m: value of the actual diameter in meters
calculette.infobulle_D_kpc: value of the actual diameter in kiloparsecs
calculette.infobulle_theta: value of the apparent diameter in arcseconds
calculette.infobulle_Calcul_inverse: Allows obtaining the values of z corresponding to a distance or time by dichotomy
calculette.infobulle_dm_inv: value of the metric distance in meters
calculette.infobulle_tem_inv: value of the time at the moment of photon emission in years
calculette.infobulle_trec_inv: value of the time at the moment of photon reception in years
calculette.infobulle_z_neg: to be checked if you want to obtain a negative z in the calculation with distance
calculette.infobulle_horizon: Calculates the distance with the event and particle horizon based on the current universe time
calculette.infobulle_t_horizon: value of the time in years for which we want to obtain the cosmological horizons in seconds
calculette.infobulle_deven: distance of the event horizon in billion light-years
calculette.infobulle_dpart: distance of the particle horizon in billion light-years
calculette.infobulle_dit: generates a graph of metric distance, luminosity distance, apparent diameter distance, and light-travel distance as a function of time
calculette.infobulle_diz: generates a graph of metric distance, luminosity distance, apparent diameter distance, and light-travel distance as a function of the spectral redshift
calculette.infobulle_omegaiz: generates a graph of cosmological density parameters as a function of time
calculette.infobulle_omegait: generates a graph of cosmological density parameters as a function of the spectral redshift
calculette.infobulle_zt: Generates a graph of the spectral redshift depending on time
calculette.infobulle_tz: Generates a graph of time depending on the spectral shift
calculette.infobulle_Tz1: Temperature at the spectral shift z1
calculette.infobulle_Tz2: Temperature at the spectral shift z2
calculette.infobulle_Hz1: Expansion rate at the spectral shift z1
calculette.infobulle_Hz2: Expansion rate at the spectral shift z2
calculette.infobulle_orz1: Radiation density parameter at the spectral shift z1
calculette.infobulle_orz2: Radiation density parameter at the spectral shift z2
calculette.infobulle_omz1: Matter density parameter at the spectral shift z1
calculette.infobulle_omz2: Matter density parameter at the spectral shift z2
calculette.infobulle_okz1: Curvature density parameter at the spectral shift z1
calculette.infobulle_okz2: Curvature density parameter at the spectral shift z2
calculette.infobulle_olz1: Lambda density parameter at the spectral shift z1
calculette.infobulle_olz2: Lambda density parameter at the spectral shift z2
calculette.infobulle_odez1: Dark matter density parameter at the spectral shift z1
calculette.infobulle_odez2: Dark matter density parameter at the spectral shift z2
calculette.infobulle_odenz1: Normalized dark matter density parameter at the spectral shift z1
calculette.infobulle_odenz2: Normalized dark matter density parameter at the spectral shift z2
calculette.infobulle_dm1: Metric distance at the spectral shift z1
calculette.infobulle_dm2: Metric distance at the spectral shift z2
calculette.infobulle_delta_dm: Difference in metric distance between z1 and z2
calculette.infobulle_delta_t: Difference in time between z1 and z2
calculette.infobulle_z1: Value of the spectral redshift at the time of photon emission
calculette.infobulle_z2: Value of the spectral redshift at the time of photon emission
calculette.infobulle_dz1: Derivative of the spectral shift z1
calculette.infobulle_dz2: Derivative of the spectral shift z2
calculette.infobulle_dl1: Luminosity distance at the spectral shift z1
calculette.infobulle_dl2: Luminosity distance at the spectral shift z2
calculette.infobulle_da1: Apparent-diameter distance at the spectral shift z1
calculette.infobulle_da2: Apparent-diameter distance at the spectral shift z2
calculette.infobulle_E1: Brightness at the spectral shift z1
calculette.infobulle_E2: Brightness at the spectral shift z2
calculette.infobulle_mu1: Distance modulus at the spectral shift z1
calculette.infobulle_mu2: Distance modulus at the spectral shift z2
calculette.avertissement_nbb: Warning, following calculations may be wrong or incoherent in the currently simulated universe
calculette.infoNomFichier: Graph save name. Do not use special characters such as . * / | + \ and others

constante.c: Speed of light in a vacuum
constante.typeAnnée: You can choose the type of year, which changes the number of days per year
constante.alerteConstante: Unable to find the parent window

Apropos.desc: Cosmogravity is an application coded as part of the Master 1 in Digital Physics at the Montpellier Faculty of Science. It allows you to use general relativity to simulate:
Apropos.desc1: the evolution of the Universe and its observational consequences with the standard cosmological model ΛCDM and with the dark energy option instead of Λ.
Apropos.desc2: dynamic trajectories (ballistic or driven) in the vicinity of a massive object (including a black hole) using the Schwarzschild metric and the Kerr metric.
Apropos.desc3: For Universe simulations, the supervisors recommend using the 2023r version of L.U.P.M. (click 'Back to LUPM')

pages_trajectoire.txt_explosion: Limited bounce at impact speed < 300 m/s
pages_trajectoire.decalageSpec_EnergyReserve: If Distant Observer, spectral shift is displayed. If lone Spationaut, energy consumed is displayed.
pages_trajectoire.r3: it is (by default) in a direction perpendicular to the orbit plane (and screen) and at a constant distance both >> rS and << H0/c²
pages_trajectoire.ctreastre: Initial distance of projectile to the center of the celestial body
pages_trajectoire.vitesse_orbite_circulaire: Circular orbit speed for this r0 (ɸ₀ = 90°)
pages_trajectoire.rayon_orbite_circulaire_photon: Initial distance of projectile to the center of the celestial body for a circular orbit (ɸ₀ = 90°)
pages_trajectoire.rayon_orbite_circulaire_photon_kerr_prog: Initial distance of projectile to the center of the celestial body for a prograde circular orbit (ɸ₀ = 90°)
pages_trajectoire.rayon_orbite_circulaire_photon_kerr_retr: Initial distance of projectile to the center of the celestial body for a retrograde circular orbit (ɸ₀ = -90°)
pages_trajectoire.vitesse_orbite_circulaire_kerr_prograde: Prograde circular orbit speed for this r0 (ɸ₀ = 90°)
pages_trajectoire.vitesse_orbite_circulaire_kerr_retrograd: Retrograde circular orbit speed for this r0 (ɸ₀ = -90°)
pages_trajectoire.diffderive: Difference in second derivatives of r
pages_trajectoire.txt_rphysique: Physical Radius of the celestial body
pages_trajectoire.infobulle_depasser: Caution : This calculation is not guaranteed beyond Rh+
pages_trajectoire.vitesseuphilabeltau: Angle of the initial speed of the projectile
pages_trajectoire.vitesse_limite: Particle is moving faster than light speed!
pages_trajectoire.rayonPhyInfHorz: Physical radius less than horizon radius!
pages_trajectoire.rayonHorzInfRayonSchw: Please enter an r0 value strictly greater than the Schwarzschild radius.
pages_trajectoire.rphysetrs: Physical radius too close to Schwarzschild radius
pages_trajectoire.rayonHorzInfRayon: Please enter an r0 value strictly greater than outer horizon Rh+!
pages_trajectoire.lancerInterdit: Launching from within the physical radius is prohibited!
pages_trajectoire.avertissement:
Trajectory simulations respect kinematics. For certain initial conditions, the calculation step becomes too large near the periastrons, leading to errors in the subsequent trajectory.

The “Decelerate” button enables you to overcome these numerical difficulties (most of the time) by interactively decreasing the calculation step.

For the calculation of velocities, we assume that a fixed observer (following a geodesic) measures the velocity of the moving object as it passes its position.

When r is less than rs, there can be no geodesic with the above property, so no observer can remain fixed. So once rs is exceeded, the speed is no longer displayed.
pages_trajectoire.avertissementSCH2:
Trajectory simulations respect kinematics. For certain initial conditions, the calculation step becomes too large near the periastrons, leading to errors in the subsequent trajectory.

The “Decelerate” button enables you to overcome these numerical difficulties (most of the time) by interactively decreasing the calculation step.

For the calculation of velocities, we assume that a fixed observer (following a geodesic) measures the velocity of the moving object as it passes its position. For a photon, this velocity remains constant.

When r is less than rs, there can be no geodesic with the above property, so no observer can remain fixed. So once rs is exceeded, the speed is no longer displayed.
pages_trajectoire.avertissementSCH3:
Trajectory simulations respect kinematics. For certain initial conditions, the calculation step becomes too large near the periastrons, leading to errors in the subsequent trajectory.

Moreover, numerically calculated trajectories in the vicinity of r=0 are sometimes unpredictable (geodesic equations have “r” in the denominator).

By interactively decreasing the calculation step, the “Decelerate” button (most of the time) overcomes these numerical difficulties.

To calculate velocities, we assume that a fixed observer (following a geodesic) measures the velocity of the moving object as it passes its position.
pages_trajectoire.avertissementSCH4:
Trajectory simulations respect kinematics. For certain initial conditions, the calculation step becomes too large near the periastrons, leading to errors in the subsequent trajectory.

Moreover, numerically calculated trajectories in the vicinity of r=0 are sometimes unpredictable (geodesic equations have “r” in the denominator).

By interactively decreasing the calculation step, the “Decelerate” button (most of the time) overcomes these numerical difficulties.

To calculate velocities, we assume that a fixed observer (following a geodesic) measures the velocity of the moving object as it passes through its position. For a photon, this velocity remains constant.
pages_trajectoire.avertissementKERR:
Trajectory simulations respect kinematics. For certain initial conditions, the calculation step becomes too large near the periastrons, leading to errors in the subsequent trajectory.

The “Decelerate” button enables you to overcome these numerical difficulties (most of the time) by interactively decreasing the calculation step.

For the calculation of velocities, we assume that a fixed observer (following a geodesic) measures the velocity of the moving object as it passes its position.

When r is less than rs, there can be no geodesic with the above property, so no observer can remain fixed. Once rs is exceeded, the speed is no longer displayed. The sudden change in rotation of the mobile's trajectory (astronaut option) at Rh+/Rh- is predicted in the theory.
pages_trajectoire.avertissementKERR2:
Trajectory simulations respect kinematics. For certain initial conditions, the calculation step becomes too large near the periastrons, leading to errors in the subsequent trajectory.

The “Decelerate” button enables you to overcome these numerical difficulties (most of the time) by interactively decreasing the calculation step.

For the calculation of velocities, we assume that a fixed observer (following a geodesic) measures the velocity of the moving object as it passes its position. For a photon, this velocity remains constant.

When r is less than rs, there can be no geodesic with the above property, so no observer can remain fixed. Once rs is exceeded, the speed is no longer displayed. The abrupt change in rotation of the photon's trajectory (photon option) at Rh+/Rh- is predicted in the theory.
pages_trajectoire.commandes_horsSchwarMassif:
Keyboard Commands List: 

- Full Trajectory: key a 
- Simple Trajectory: key z
- With or Without Bounce: key e 
- Reset: key s 
- Save: key d 
- Slow down simulation: key w 
- Pause / Play: key x 
- Speed up simulation: key c
pages_trajectoire.theta_label: Angle of initial speed of projectile
pages_trajectoire.philabel: Angle of initial position of projectile
pages_trajectoire.Vlibtitle: Escape Speed at the Surface of the Celestial Body
pages_trajectoire.nombre_g_infobulle: Number of g felt by the pilot with 1g = 9.81m/s². Valid only for Newtonian mechanics.
pages_trajectoire.dernier_g_infobulle: Last non-zero g felt by the pilot with 1g = 9.81m/s². Valid only for Newtonian mechanics.
pages_trajectoire.distance_metrique_parcourue_infobulle: Metric distance traveled by the mobile since initial moment.
pages_trajectoire.pourcentage_vphi_infobulle: Percentage of tangential speed used for piloting. Reactor acceleration time is 50 ms.
pages_trajectoire.puissance_consommee_infobulle: Instantaneous power consumed by reactors in W/kg.
pages_trajectoire.alerte_v0_superieure_c: Warning, your initial speed v0 is greater than c.
pages_trajectoire.alerte_r0_inferieure_rs: Warning, your initial distance r0 to the center of the celestial body is smaller than the Schwarzschild radius.
pages_trajectoire.alerte_singularite_non_baryonique: Mobile stops, calculation is unstable, decelerate next time.
pages_trajectoire.alerte_verifier_r0: Warning, please enter the value of r₀.
pages_trajectoire.alerte_verifier_M: Warning, please enter the value of M.
pages_trajectoire.alerte_verifier_v0: Warning, please enter the value of v₀.
pages_trajectoire.alerte_verifier_phi0: Warning, please enter the value of the initial position angle.
pages_trajectoire.alerte_verifier_teta: Warning, please enter the value of ɸ₀.
pages_trajectoire.alerte_verifier_rphy: Warning, please enter the value of the physical radius.
pages_trajectoire.alerte_verifier_J: Warning, please enter the value of angular momentum J.
pages_trajectoire.alerte_verifier_nbrefusees: Warning, please enter the value of number of rockets.
pages_trajectoire.label_choix_potentiel_infobulle: Allows real-time selection of the potential graph to display

page_trajectoire_massive.titre: Massive Projectile Trajectory in Schwarzschild Metric
page_trajectoire_massive.particule_arretee: Projectile has landed on the surface of the celestial body.
page_trajectoire_massive.particule_ecrasee: Projectile has crashed onto the surface of the celestial body.
page_trajectoire_massive.amortissement: Damping coefficient: Limited bounce at impact speed < 300 m/s

page_trajectoire_massive_nonBar.titre:
Massive Projectile Trajectory in Schwarzschild Metric
(non-baryonic case)

page_trajectoire_photon_nonBar.titre:
Photon Trajectory in Schwarzschild Metric
(non-baryonic case)
page_trajectoire_photon_nonBar.orbite_circulaire_exterieure: Photon's required distance from the celestial body's center for a circular orbit outside the body (ɸ₀ = 90°).
page_trajectoire_photon_nonBar.orbite_circulaire_interieure: Photon's required distance from the celestial body's center for a circular orbit inside the body (ɸ₀ = 90°).

page_trajectoire_massive_kerr.titre: Massive Particle Trajectory in Kerr Metric
